message_1:
Evaluate the following contour integral:

$$
\int_C \frac{\sin(z)}{z-2} dz 
$$

where $C$ is the circle of radius 3 centered at the origin, traversed counterclockwise.
message_2:
To evaluate the contour integral, we will use the residue theorem. The residue theorem states that for a function with isolated singularities inside a simple closed contour, the integral of the function around the contour is equal to $2\pi i$ times the sum of the residues of the function at its singularities inside the contour.

In this case, the function is $f(z) = \frac{\sin(z)}{z-2}$, and it has a simple pole at $z = 2$. Since the contour $C$ is a circle of radius 3 centered at the origin, the pole at $z = 2$ is inside the contour.

Now, we need to find the residue of the function at the pole. The residue of a function with a simple pole at $z = z_0$ can be found using the formula:

$$
\text{Res}(f, z_0) = \lim_{z \to z_0} (z - z_0) f(z)
$$

In our case, $z_0 = 2$, so we have:

$$
\text{Res}(f, 2) = \lim_{z \to 2} (z - 2) \frac{\sin(z)}{z-2}
$$

The limit simplifies to:

$$
\text{Res}(f, 2) = \lim_{z \to 2} \sin(z) = \sin(2)
$$

Now, we can apply the residue theorem:

$$
\int_C \frac{\sin(z)}{z-2} dz = 2\pi i \cdot \text{Res}(f, 2) = 2\pi i \cdot \sin(2)
$$

So, the value of the contour integral is:

$$
\int_C \frac{\sin(z)}{z-2} dz = 2\pi i \sin(2)
$$
